title: Arhitecture book typeface
content:
as much as it looks like handwriting, it is featured as body typeface in an architecture book. any ideas, please?   
   
 ![architecture book typeface](http://web.archive.org/web/20050515203706im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/70537.jpg)
author: nisioiugeorge

comments.content:
This is hand-lettered for sure.   
   
As Mike would say, there are ton of fonts that closely mimic handwriting. You can search any of the font sites like Myfonts or Dafont and find tons of them. Or go to Mike's site: www.bowfinprintworks.com and search his archive.

It is handwriting. None of the letters are exactly the same. But you can get a pretty similar feeling with [Sketchley](http://web.archive.org/web/20050515203706/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/sketchley-bt/).

I couldn't have said it better Patty.   
   
This style of hand-printed lettering is mostly in [Part 11 of the Script Font ID Guide](http://web.archive.org/web/20050515203706/http:/bowfinprintworks.com/Script11Pg1.html), but some more formal-looking printed hand lettering is found in Part 6 (fonts like Tekton, Stylus, Blueprint, etc.).

can we imagine a full book being handwritten :-?   
you seem to be right, I myself noticed the differences ...   
   
actually, it's a 400 page 1965 book on Le Corbusier

![](http://web.archive.org/web/20050515203706im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/70540.gif)   
   
I think [Marydale](http://web.archive.org/web/20050515203706/http:/www.typequarry.com/type.html?sku=016) is an excelent alternative.
